tn.text: "Word" is metonymy for what a person says. See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:06:11|6:11]]. AT: "Yahweh spoke his word" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"cause rain to fall on the land"

The word "now" is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the writer tells background information about how the famine had affected Samaria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
The word "Now" is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here the writer tells about a new person in the story.

tn.ref: one hundred prophets and hid them by fifties
tn.text: "100 prophets and hid them in groups of 50" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: save the horses and mules alive ... not lose all the animals
tn.text: These two phrases mean basically the same thing and are combined for emphasis. AT: "prevent the horses and mules from dying" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: Ahab went one way by himself and Obadiah went another way
tn.text: The phrase "by himself" emphasizes that Ahab and Obadiah went in separate directions, not necessarily that no one was with Ahab. AT: "Ahab lead a team in one direction and Obadiah lead a team in the other direction" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the word "master" is used as a term of respect.

tn.ref: Go tell your master, 'Look, Elijah is here.'
tn.text: Here the word "master" refers to Ahab.
The word "Look" here adds emphasis to what follows.

tn.ref: How have I sinned ... for him to kill me?
tn.text: Obadiah asks this question to emphasize the danger to himself because of King Ahab's anger at Elijah. AT: "I have not wronged you ... for him to kill me." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: give your servant into the hand of Ahab
tn.text: "Hand" is metonymy for power and control. AT: "deliver your servant to Ahab" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Obadiah refers to himself as Elijah's servant in order to honor Elijah.
This is an oath used to emphasize that what he is saying is true.

tn.ref: there is no nation ... where my master has not sent men
tn.text: This can be expressed positively. AT: "my master has sent men everywhere" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublenegatives]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])
This phrase is used to emphasize the danger in what Elijah is telling Obadiah to do.

tn.ref: Has it not been told to you ... with bread and water?
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "Surely you have been told about what I did ... with bread and water!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "master" is a term of respect used to refer to Elijah.

tn.ref: one hundred of Yahweh's prophets by fifties
tn.text: "100 of Yahweh's prophets in groups of 50" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: Go and tell your master that Elijah is here
tn.text: Translate this quotation as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:18:09|18:11]].
Here "master" refers to King Ahab.
This is an oath to emphasize that what he will say is true.
To "stand before" is an idiom for being in someone's presence and ready to serve him. AT: "whom I serve" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Obadiah told Ahab what Elijah had told him to say"

tn.ref: Is it you? You are the one who brings trouble to Israel!
tn.text: Ahab asks the question for emphasis to be certain about Elijah's identity. AT: "So here you are. You are the troublemaker of Israel!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

This is a generalization to refer to the leaders and people who represent the ten tribes of the northern kingdom. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"four hundred and fifty prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"400 prophets" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

"Word" is metonymy for what a person says. This is a common statement used with the meaning understood. AT: "sent a message" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: How long will you keep changing your mind?
tn.text: Elijah asks this question to urge the people to make a decision. AT: "You have been indecisive for long enough." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

tn.ref: did not answer him a word
tn.text: "did not say anything" or "were silent"
The word "I" is repeated for emphasis.

tn.ref: call on the name of your god ... call on the name of Yahweh
tn.text: "Name" is metonymy for the reputation and honor of someone and "calling on" him represents an appeal. AT: "call to your god ... call to Yahweh" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: all the people answered and said, "This is good."
tn.text: "all the people said, 'This is a good thing to do.'"
"make it ready to be sacrificed"
Here the word "you" is plural. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_youdual]])
"The prophets of Baal took the bull"

tn.ref: the bull that was given to them
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the bull that someone gave them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: But there was no voice, nor anyone who answered
tn.text: These two phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that there was no one to respond to the prayers of the false prophets. AT: "But Baal did not say or do anything" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Maybe" or "It could be that"
This euphemism is a more pleasant way to express a harsh statement. Elijah uses understatement to insult Baal with sarcasm. AT: "in the bathroom" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "you must awaken him" or "you must wake him up" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

"they continued their wild behavior." Prophets often acted in ways that seemed unusual or even crazy. In this case they were calling on Baal while dancing, shouting loudly, and cutting themselves with knives.

tn.ref: of offering of the evening sacrifice
tn.text: "to offer the evening sacrifice"

tn.ref: but there was no voice or anyone to answer; there was no one who paid any attention to their pleadings
tn.text: These phrases share similar meanings and emphasize that no one responded to the prayers of the false prophets. AT: "but Baal did not say or do anything or even pay attention" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: there was no voice or anyone to answer
tn.text: Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:18:25|18:26]].
"12 stones" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"Name" is a metonymy for honor and reputation. Possible meanings are 1) "to honor Yahweh" or 2) "with the authority of Yahweh." (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
a small waterway to hold water
A seah is a unit of volume equal to about 7.7 liters. AT: "about 15 liters of seeds" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_bvolume]])

tn.ref: He arranged the wood for a fire
tn.text: "On the altar" where he placed the wood is assumed in this sentence. AT: "He put the wood for a fire on the altar" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
"4 jars" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
A jar is a container for water.
Translate this as in [[:en:bible:notes:1ki:18:30]].
This phrase is used here to reference a significant and meaningful time of the day in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: Yahweh, the God of Abraham, of Isaac, and of Israel
tn.text: Here "Israel" is referring to Jacob. God changed Jacob's name to Israel (Genesis 32:28), and God named the nation of Jacob's descendants "Israel."

tn.ref: let it be known this day
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "make these people know today" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This phrase is repeated to emphasize the appeal of Elijah to Yahweh.

tn.ref: turned their heart back again to yourself
tn.text: "turn their heart" is a metonymy for the affection and loyalty of the people. AT: "caused them to be loyal to you again" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"the fire of Yahweh came down"
The fire is compared to a thirsty person drinking water. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Yahweh, he is God! Yahweh, he is God!
tn.text: This phrase is repeated for emphasis.
A "brook" is a small stream or watercourse. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: there is the sound of much rain
tn.text: "it sounds like it is going to rain a lot"

tn.ref: bowed himself down on the earth and put his face between his knees
tn.text: This describes a posture used for praying.
The word "seven" can be rendered as the numeral "7." AT: "7 times" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: as small as a man's hand
tn.text: From a long distance, the cloud could be covered from sight by a man's hand.
This phrase is used here to mark where a new step in the action starts. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: the hand of Yahweh was on Elijah
tn.text: Here the word "hand" is a metonymy for strength. AT: "Yahweh gave his power to Elijah" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: tucked his robe in his belt
tn.text: Elijah wrapped his long robe around his waist so that his legs would be free for running.
